5.0 (3.3–7.0)] with significant differences (Kruskal–Wallis test, p Perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA) Interstitial lung disease Dust Inhalation Polymerization of tetrafluoroethylene pmc-status-qastatus 0 pmc-status-live yes pmc-status-embargo no pmc-status-released yes pmc-prop-open-access yes pmc-prop-olf no pmc-prop-manuscript no pmc-prop-legally-suppressed no pmc-prop-has-pdf yes pmc-prop-has-supplement yes pmc-prop-pdf-only no pmc-prop-suppress-copyright no pmc-prop-is-real-version no pmc-prop-is-scanned-article no pmc-prop-preprint no pmc-prop-in-epmc yes Introduction PFAS (s), per- and polyfluoroalkyl substance (s), are the class of synthetic chemicals that have been produced from 1940s 1 ) PFAS exposure has been shown to be associated with adverse health effects, including immunotoxicity, impairing lipid metabolism, fetal and
child growth inhibition and kidney cancer and other diseases 2 3 ) 4 ) In 2002, high levels of PFOA contamination were discovered in the Yodo River system in Osaka Prefecture in Japan 5 ) 6 ) Our group at Kyoto University has been monitoring drinking water, meals, atmosphere, and human blood, continuing to observe the decrease in
Keihanshin area 7 8 9 ) 6 ) 10 ) 11 ) The C8 health project is well-known in research regarding the blood levels of PFAS in workers and residents 12 13 ) 13 ) 14 ) 15 ) There have been several reports regarding the exposure media and health effects for end-user workers using commercial products from
fluorochemical maker industries 16 17 18 ) 16 17 18 ) 19 ) 18 ) The major aims of this study are twofold. For workers in DIYP, the exact exposure routes and kinetic aspects are elusive. Thus we first focus
on former and current DIYP workers and, by comparing them to residents, to chase serum concentrations of PFOA in former and current workers
under a condition without occupational exposures. Although several cases with pulmonary diseases have been reported in end-user workers 16 17 18 19 ) Subjects and Methods Study design and study population (Fig. 1) As mentioned in the introduction, the wells adjacent to the east of DIYP still showed high levels of PFOA concentration according to
surveys by Osaka prefecture in Japan 10 ) In 2023, a Blood Monitoring Campaign was launched voluntarily by residents in the northern Osaka region where DIYP is located, in
collaboration with Kyoto University and the Osaka Miniren, which is a social movement organization consisting of public interest
incorporated associations and various medical, nursing, and caregiving establishments, including hospitals and 47 medical clinics, that
operate in the Osaka Prefecture in Japan 20 ) At the time of blood sampling, 12 to18 ml of blood was collected from the cubital vein. Participants were asked to complete a
self-administered questionnaire. The questionnaire collected information such as birth date, height, weight, residential history, medical
history (including thyroid disease, lipid metabolism disorders, heart disease, liver disease, diabetes, hypertension, ulcerative colitis,
allergies, testicular cancer, kidney cancer, pregnancy-related abnormalities), use of constipation medication, smoking history, alcohol
consumption, use of tap water, well water, water filters, consumption of home-grown produce, fish and seafood intake, use of AFFF,
occupational exposure, and COVID-19 illness history. However, in the initial farming residents study, the medical history was open-ended.
Since this study focuses on workers’ PFOA exposure, the analysis was limited to specific factors. For the former and current Daikin workers, detailed interviews were conducted about their work environments, and five participants with
high PFOA exposure underwent medical examinations. Participants were assigned their ages when they participated in the Blood Monitoring Campaign. Those who did not participate in the Blood
Monitoring Campaign were assigned the ages in which they had at the time of their first blood monitoring. Former and current workers
requested to conceal personal information to identify individuals. Thus ages were not shown on the individual basis. Assessment of PFOA exposure Serum was separated by centrifugation conventionally. Serum samples were analyzed by gas chromatography (GC) or liquid chromatography (LC)
and mass spectrometer (MS) to determine PFAS concentrations. In GC analysis, to 0.10 ml of serum sample, 0.4 ml of acetonitrile and surrogate standard solution (EPA-533ES, Wellington Laboratories,
Canada) were mixed, centrifuged to remove protein and the supernatant was allowed to dryness. Bis (4-tert-phenyl) iodonium
hexafluorophosphate (tBPI, Tokyo Kasei Kogyo, Japan) was used as the reagent for in-port derivatization. Each sample extract was dissolved
in a 1% (w/v) tBPI/Acetone solution and used for injection to GC-MS. PFAS was separated by Agilent 6890N GC inert using DB-5MS (30 m ×
0.25 mm, 0.25 μm thickness) with splitless injection at an inlet temperature of 300°C. PFAS were measured by 5973N MSD under chemical
ionization (methane gas, negative ionization mode) 21 ) In LC analysis, automated pretreatment system was used for extraction of PFAS (Extrahera classic, Biotage AB, Uppsala, Sweden) based on a
US EPA 1633 method 22 ) 13 ® For serum analyses, standard reference material SRM 1957 of US National Institute of Standards and Technology was used for confirmation of
accuracy and reproducibility. We determined serum concentrations by both GC-MS and LC-MS/MS and determined consistency between GC-MS and
LC-MS/MS analysis ( Supplementary Table and Fig 2 p Hundred milliliter water sample was divided and mixed with a 13 Soil samples were extracted and analyzed using the following method. Twenty five milliliter of acetonitrile, 2 ml of 200 mM NaOH and 10 µl

serum levels, as predicted by the biological half-life, was not observed ( Table 4 Occupational and clinical investigation The manufacturing processes involved with PTFE for the five former or current workers (W1–W5) were as follows at DIYP 24 ) 25 ) 25 ) 6 ) W1: A male worker who worked in the suspension polymerization process from the 1970s to the mid-2010s. He recognized the dustiness of the
workplace and wore the provided dust mask. However, when working in the office away from the production area, he sometimes removed the mask,
and dust would frequently accumulate on his clothing. After leaving DIYP in the mid-2010s, he continued to undergo annual health checkups.
In 2021, chest X-rays revealed nodular and granular shadows in his lungs, along with pleural changes. In 2022, he was diagnosed with
suspected interstitial pneumonia, and further tests confirmed the diagnosis. He was diagnosed with COVID-19 in January 2023. His current
symptoms include frequent coughing, excessive sputum, hoarseness, and weight loss. He has a smoking history between the ages of 20–40 yr,
but he quit smoking. Computerize Tomography (CT) scans showed early signs of interstitial pulmonary fibrosis ( Fig. 3A Fig. 3. CT scan of the chest from W1–W5 cases. A: W1, B: W2, C: W4, D: W3, E: W5. An arrow indicates the early sign of interstitial lung disease (ILD). W2: A male worker who joined the company in the 1970s and worked for 5 yr in the fluoroelastomer process, followed by more than 40 yr in
the management of the fluoroelastomer process until his retirement in the mid-2010s. His office was next to W1’s work area, with poor air
sealing, and the office space was shared with W1. Before leaving DIYP, during a general health checkup, lung abnormalities were detected,
and he was later diagnosed with interstitial pneumonia. CT scans revealed lung fibrosis ( Fig. 3B W4: A male worker who worked in the same processes as W1 in the downstairs workshop from early 2000s to late 2010s until leaving DIYP. CT
scans revealed no abnormality ( Fig. 3C W3: A female worker who, from early 2010s until early 2020s, was involved in cleaning containers that had been used for shipping “Fine

ulcerative colitis and with kidney cancer at mid-40s. W7, a former smoker, had been engaged in producing aqueous fluorine-based etching
agents for semiconductor manufacturing for 18 yr until retirement. These agents contained PFOA as a surfactant. W7 had never handled “Fine
powder”. Discussion In this study, a blood biomonitoring survey was conducted on local residents around DIYP 12 yr after the complete cessation of production in
2012 6 ) 26 ) 7 8 9 ) 26 ) The results revealed that farming residents, as well as former or current workers who had been exposed to dust at DIYP, had extremely high
serum concentrations. Among the farming residents, an intervention study avoiding agricultural products grown on contaminated soil with
contaminated groundwater demonstrated a rapid decrease in serum PFOA concentrations, clearly indicating the large burden of agricultural
products. In contrast, follow-up investigations on former or current workers revealed that their concentrations deviated significantly from
the expected kinetics predicted by half-life, indicating that excretion from the body was extremely slow. Therefore, the high serum
concentrations in this group may be attributed to two possibilities: the high exposure levels at the workplace when they were active workers
and/or the very slow excretion of PFOA from their bodies. The very slow excretion observed in former and current workers is likely associated with exposure to dust particulates specific to the
workers. Among the seven former and current workers, five had high serum concentrations, and all five were related to exposure to dust
generated during the PTFE manufacturing process. The common exposure route among them strongly suggests the possibility of inhalation. Regarding the physicochemical properties of the dust, it cannot be verified through measurement as PFOA was no longer used as a surfactant in
this “Molding Powder” producing process. However, in the suspension polymerization process for PTFE production, Daikin was aware of the
dust-producing work environment at that time, indicating that exposure to dust occurred for those former workers. It is possible that exposure
to intermediate products generated in such processes occurred, and the PFOA added for emulsion formation was extremely high and may remain in
the intermediate products. A report from China indicates that the concentration of such intermediate products can reach 1.1 × 10 6 27 ) 25 ) Additionally, although there is insufficient information on particle size, reports suggest that “Fine Powder” particles are extremely small,
ranging from 0.05 to 0.5 micrometers 25 ) 28 29 30 ) There have been several reports on workers who developed pulmonary diseases by long-term PTFE dust exposure 16 17 18 19 ) Given long retention of PFOA containing dust in the lung, the prolonged PFOA retention in the body has significant implications for workers’
health effects. In PTFE-related workers, two cases of interstitial pneumonia were observed, and early ILD lesions were found in another case
via CT, indicating that ILDs might be frequently found in workers exposed to PTFE-related dust. Given interstitial pneumonia in two
individuals, the minor ILD lesions in one case may likely represent the early stages of ILDs. We believe that individuals involved in
PTFE-related processes should be followed up even after retirement to assess potential harmful health effects related to their work. Likewise,
possible harm effects in general population should also be addressed since PTFE microplastics have been detected in the human lung 31 ) This study has several important limitations. First, there was limited participation from individuals associated with DIYP. Additionally, the
number of farming residents involved in the study was small, so the evidence is limited. Furthermore, participation rate cannot be calculated
for the blood monitoring campaign. Second, regarding participants associated with Daikin, information on past work processes and work
environment was constructed only from interviews and literatures, including patents, and was not based on systemic survey and monitoring in
occupational settings. Third, concerning the PFOA accumulation in the body, although the diagnosis was confirmed by clinical investigation,
the presence of PFOA-containing particles was not proven in the lung, and the conclusion is based on speculation. Fourth, due to the
self-administered nature of the questionnaire, there is a possibility of omissions or memory errors by respondents including past and current
ILDs. Furthermore, regarding PFOA measurements, branched isomer quantification was not included for total PFOA when it was below the
quantification limit. Also, the LC-MS/MS method used only measured linear form of PFOA. However, it is worth noting that of the 1,190 tests
conducted, branched isomers were detected in 467 participants, in which they accounted for only 5.8% of the total of PFOA. Thus the impact on
serum concentration is not expected to be significant, if any. On the other hand, the strength of this study lies in the intervention study, which demonstrated that agricultural products grown in
contaminated soil and water can definitively contribute as a potential source of exposure. Additionally, this study clearly demonstrated that
the excretion of PFOA is very slow in individuals who were exposed to PFOA-containing dust. Most importantly we confirmed ILDs in former and
current workers with a very high incidence. In conclusion, for workers involved in PTFE production in the past, medical examinations confirmed cases of ILDs. The risk for workers may
increase over time even after retirement. Since pulmonary lesions are typically observed more than 20 yr after exposure, it is necessary to
follow up with both current and former workers who were involved in the PTFE process or who shared a work environment with exposed workers.
Conversely, if a case of ILDs is identified among current or former workers at DIYP, it is also recommended to review their dust exposure
history related to the PTFE process. The potential for increased risk of ILDs has likely been overlooked, and it is urgent to conduct
follow-up studies on workers to understand the mechanisms and take appropriate preventive/medical actions. Finally, the relationship between
PFOA exposure and the occurrence of ILD in this study is not necessarily clear, and evidence such as macrophage function and lung damage is
needed to strengthen the associations. Author Contributions KA, KK and OT designed the investigation. KA wrote the first draft of the paper and statistically analyzed the data. HHK analyzed serum,
